items.text: Confirm any municipal EVSE requirements and EVEMS allowances. Typically in Parking or Zoning By-Laws. Examples at https://pluginbc.ca/policy/
Confirm HVAC and domestic hot water approach with mech consultant (gas vs. electric) (distributed vs. centralized HVAC condensers)
Confirm fire pump requirements with mech consultant
Confirm any specialty equipment loads at high level for preliminary load calc (kitchen, IT, processing, etc.)
Confirm potential CRU tenants with client and allocate loads for shell spaces (kitchen, data centre, food stores, etc.)
Preliminary load calculations completed to determine service size and type from utility
Preliminary generator load calculations completed
Dwelling unit transformer calculations completed
Lightning protection analysis has been conducted per CSA B72
Review architectural drawings for changes. Rezoning or DP comments often lead to significant changes that can impact load calculations. Update load calc if required.
Check architectural drawings to ensure all requested SD provisions have been incorporated (rooms, shafts, etc).
Procure preliminary motorlist from mechanical consultant. Update load calculation with information provided.
Coordinate with client to lock-in any decisions that affect loads (CRU tenant types, uses of amenity spaces, client equipment, etc.) Update load calc if required.
Load calculations are provided on drawings, major equipment load calcs have been peer reviewed
Clearances from building to utility power lines confirmed. Consider additional clearance may be required so that construction workers are not within limits of approach (WorkSafe BC Req.)
Clearances from building to utilty pole transformers confirmed.
Survey drawing and land title procured by Owner and reviewed to confirm no statutory rights-of-way are on the property for existing utility services.
ESI form filled out (service application form), submitted to utility with SLD and arch plans
Vista switch requirements confirmed by utility
Location of available power service confirmed by utility (which street / frontage)
Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk locations confirmed with utility
Utility ROWs are clear of other structures and services. No structure above or below ROW areas when required by utility.
Location of electrical service equipment as close as possible to service entrance
Location of electrical service equipment is above flood elevation
Access to and location of utility service rooms and rooms containing metering equipment comply with utility requirements
Submit a revised service application (ESI Form) to the utility if updated load calc shows an increase from the SD application. Reconfirm vista switch requirements if applicable.
Revenue meters conform to utility requirements (locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments & conduit details, sealing provisions, comm provisions)
Confirm size and quantity of incoming service ducts with utility
Send utility service entrance duct profile, site plan, and service room layout for initial review and comments
Make formal service application to utility
North arrows shown on plans, not shown on schematics / details
Company logos and disclaimer shown, no frames around logos, reflects current AES office locations
Room names and room numbers shown
Drawing titles, subtitles, and discipline shown
Drawing notes are project-specific, coordinated with design
Scale bars shown (plot independent), original sheet size marked
Title block and sheet size matches architectural
Drawing numbering format matches architectural
Symbol schedule includes all symbols, matches all drawings
Drawing list includes all drawings, matches all drawings
Energy code compliance statement
Statement of compliance with code consultant's report and/or alternate solutions summary
Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk locations shown. Indicate dimensions of all clearances and ROW areas.
Utility service duct routing shown. Ducts are to utility standards for size, quantity, number of bends, etc.
T-drains indicated for all utility ducts before entering building.
Service entrance duct profile detailed.
Service ducts indicated as concrete encased for any portion run inside the building
All HV ducts indicated as RGS where run inside building
Electrical service and comm entrance facility room locations shown
Existing services shown
Phasing shown, circuits maintained / replaced where affected by demolition or relocation.  Temporary provisions detailed.
Provisions for future expansions shown.
Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk grounding details complete. Connections to building rebar and exposed metal parts indicated and project specific.
All sections of ductbanks detailed (depth, spacing, etc., including lighting and signage ducts, pullboxes, manholes)
Concrete encasement of ductbanks indicated (if applicable)
Pull boxes indicated for long duct runs or runs with multiple bends. Use of pull boxes approved by utilities.
Engine block heater receptacles shown (cold regions only), IPLC or similar energy controls specified
Electric vehicle supply equipment locations shown
Power for building signage
Light pole base detailed
Bollard base detailed (lighting or EVSE)
Parking gate / kiosk pedestal base detailed
Weatherproof enclosures detailed (also check other floor plan sheets where exterior devices are indicated)
Drawings are coordinated with mech, arch, civil, landscape plans (device locations, physical conflicts, phasing conflicts)
Confirm with client if separate common area meters are required for different occupancies in mixed-use buildings (eg. separate commercial and residential common area meters)
Provide separate utility revenue meters for house loads, each dwelling unit, each CRU, EVSE distribution, Fire Pumps
No utility revenue meters are downstream of other utillity revenue meters
Temporary master revenue meters are provided where required (upstream of all utility revenue meters)
Information metering shown, if required by Energy Code or Client request
Generator size indicated
Fully rated 100% generator load bank test breaker provided, accessible load bank connection terminals
Generator load bank breaker connected directly to the emergency generator (ie. Load bank breaker is not downstream of the main generator breaker)
Separate transfer switches for life safety and non-life-safety emergency distribution (or vital / delayed vital / conditional in a healthcare facility)
Outdoor Generators: 208V/1PH connection shown to generator for integral panel that feeds coolant heaters, battery charger, maintenance receptacles (confirm size with manufacturer)
Parallel Generators: Means to automatically reduce load in the event of a single generator failure provided to ensure continuation of emergency power. (multiple transfer switches)
Fire pump normal power supply has no breakers or disconnect devices between the FP breaker and the service box (ie. FP breaker is not downstream of the main service breaker)
Fire pump emergency breaker connected directly to the emergency generator (ie. FP breaker is not downstream of the main generator breaker)
Fire pump uses separate ATS. FP and ATS noted as supplied by mechanical
Ground fault protection on circuits of solidly grounded systems rated at and greater than 2000A (208V) and 1000A (600V)
Ground fault detection for all ungrounded/impedance grounded systems
System neutrals grounded at the correct locations, single point per system: service box, generator X0, transformer X0, first switch or tie point

Systems with multiple sources use either 3-wire distribution / 3-pole ATS or 4-wire / 4-pole ATS & main-tie-mains (separately derived); any other 4-wire system types (i.e. commonly derived) must carefully consider parallel neutral/ground return paths to avoid stray currents / ground fault detection problems
Grounding detail provided. Ground bus on detail shown connected at service box.
All circuit breaker and fuse sizes shown (frame, trip, LI/LSI/LSIG, 100% ratings as required).  LSI/LSIG breakers recommended for feeders over 400A.

Fire pump breaker / wire sizing is correct, typically 600% FLA utility side, 300% FLA gen side breakers, breakers labeled and lockable, will not trip before breaker in fire pump controller.  FLA, breaker sizing, and tripping coordination to be confirmed based on fire pump shop drawings.
Selective coordination of protective devices specified where required
All conduit, wire and bus sizes shown, conductor ampacity matches protective devices, 3-wire vs. 4-wire indicated, bonding wires indicated
A neutral conductor is provided to all in-line meter bases (â‰¤ 200A), including those serving 3-phase, 3-wire loads (BCH Secondary Metering Guide requirement)
Interrupting capacity of o/c devices shown, available fault current calculation is provided, consistent with specs and panel schedules
Series-rated combinations clearly identified if used, with permanent labels
All equipment designations and locations shown (including LV relay panels, meter cabinets, etc.)
Power conditioning or surge protection shown
Transformer sizes shown
K-Ratings of transformers indicated, if applicable
Future spares or spaces indicated
Key interlocks shown, sequence of operations description correct, match utility requirements
Protection (fire / circuit integrity rating) of emergency conductors is specified
Wires and cables selected using 75 Deg C ampacity
Underground wires and cables derated as required
No unrelated equipment in HV equipment rooms (e.g. FACP, piping, mech or comm equipment)
HV equipment rooms not located below living space where possible. If unavoidable, confirm acoustic considerations with architect and coordinate drains to not run through room.
Generator rooms not located below living space where possible. If unavoidable, confirm acoustic considerations with architect.
Generator fuel / exhaust / ventilation requirements coordinated with arch and mech
Generator fuel tanks sized to C282, Z32, and NFPA 20 requirements (8-hours for fire pumps per NFPA 20 Article 9.6.2.3)
Generator Room is located above the flood elevation
Generator is located within 1 storey of grade where required in accordance with CSA Z32 (health care facilities).
Sub-Electrical and Communication Rooms are located above the flood elevation if required by municipal by-laws
Future replacement of large equipment (unit subs, generators) has been considered in locating service rooms.
Electrical and Communications service rooms sized. Markups of locations, dimensions, and fire ratings sent to architect for coordination.
Routing of major electrical and communication feeders planned. Shafts and riser spaces marked up and sent to architect for coordination.
Generator room is 2hr rated and contains only equipment related to the emergency power supply system.
Generator has 1m clearance on all sides except the exhaust air duct end.
If multiple generators are in the same room, required 1m clearances of each generator do not overlap.
Clearances around electrical equipment (1m min.)
Clearances around electrical equipment increased to 1.5m min. when there is only one exit path and equipment is rated 1200A or more, or over 750V.
HV station ground electrode / ground mat / adjacent metal bonding detailed, step and touch calculations provided, ground testing scope specified
Visible and/or remote disconnection means for all HV sources of supply
Emergency battery pack in the generator and emergency switchgear rooms (50 Lx for 2 h)
Convenience outlets shown in all service rooms and elec/comm riser closets
Housekeeping pads
Photocell and timer for exterior lighting control
Check voltage drop to exterior fixtures
Luminaire mounting compatible with ceiling type
Fixture types indicated and included on schedules
Exit Signs are required
Directional exits provided where required
Running Man exit sign upgrades outside of renovation area in accordance with local AHJ requirements (only for existing buildings with red Exit Signs)
Emergency lighting provided where required
Emergency lighting provided in all exterior egress routes (i.e. where there are stairs, pathways, etc. between door and open public thoroughfare, and on roofs to mech equipment)
Required duration of emergency power supply noted on drawings 30 min / 1 hr / 2 hr
Emergency battery packs shown, on same circuit as normal area lighting
Voltage drop to remote DC heads
Lighting levels in public areas
Light diffusers and lenses
Recessed luminaires in insulated ceilings are IC rated
Luminaires in showers, steam rooms, and other wet areas are marked suitable for use in wet locations
Check drawings with arch/millwork details (under counter, task, feature areas)
Architectural RCP matches electrical, ceiling types, fixture/device locations coordinated.  Drop ceilings shown shaded on electrical drawings.
Light/sensor locations checked for conflict with ductwork or other mechanical components.

Lights c/w wall switches provided in dwelling units as prescribed. Switched receptacle may be used in lieu of light in bedroom and living room. Provide exterior light and switch for all units with exterior access.

Lights c/w wall switches provided in dwelling units as prescribed. Switched receptacle may be used in lieu of light in bedroom and living room. Provide exterior light and switch for all units with exterior access.
Lighting meets applicable energy code (ASHRAE/NECB/Step Code), including occupancy/vacancy control, daylight harvesting, LPD limits
Switching and control zoning clearly identified
Lighting control commissioning requirements specified (commissioning by third-party)
Any low voltage lighting has a suitably close location detailed for the drivers (e.g. decorative LED lighting panels on building exterior, handrail lights, etc.)
Lights not located above any garage/loading gates/doors, or rotating fans
Wall sconces in corridors are maximum 100mm deep (if applicable)
Wall sconces in corridors do not interfere with minimum corridor width of 1100mm (if applicable)
Surface mounted ceiling lights do not interfere with minimum 2050mm clear height of corridors or exits
Service rooms do not have occupancy sensor switches
Electrical closets (not walk-in service rooms) with revenue meters are provided lights with wall switches (occupancy sensors not accepted by BC Hydro)
Master switch at suite entrance to control all lights except those serving corridors, stairs, washrooms, and rooms with no exterior window.
Override switch provided for each floor of a multi-level suite where a master switch is provided.
No light switches are located within 1m of a bath tub or shower stall. (Locate on the outside of the bathroom wall if necessary)
Battery packs in operating rooms and other areas defined in 6.5.1 of CSA Z32
Night lighting (must be justified for safety or security in projects complying with ASHRAE or NECB)
Exam/Procedure lighting
Cleanable fixtures (no ledges, sealed)
Heavier duty lenses, frames, lower harmonics, RFI screened, multi-ballasted/switched as required for specific healthcare applications
Correctional grade luminaires, including anchorage, placement, and security caulking
Vandal resistant where appropriate (locker room, washroom, exterior, corridors)
Parkade entrance lit to 550 lx, drive aisles to 110 lx, vestibules/lobbies to 220 lx
Exit signs are provided dedicated circuits, or connected to emergency lighting circuits in there area where they are installed

Combustible equipment, conduit & wiring flame spread ratings [FT6 in plenums, FT4 in non-combusitble construction, FT1 elswhere, fire-rated service rooms exempt] [3.6.4.3; 3.1.4.3.(2); 3.1.5.21.(2) of NBC]
Panel locations shown, wall thickness and fire separations suitable for flush mount panels

Suite panel is located behind a door swing, in a hallway, or in another location where furniture will not be placed in front of it. Ensure panel is not shown in any walls with fire separation ratings (corridor walls or walls separating suites), in shear walls, or in plumbing riser walls.
Control devices in barrier-free path of travel are centred on either the length or the width of a clear floor space of 1350mm by 800mm
Re-use of existing circuits / devices indicated where required
Housekeeping receptacles shown (10m spacing in residential public corridors and stairs).
Power outlets provided for low tension systems power supplies / control panels (security, A/V, PA, intercom, etc.)
Kitchen equipment coordinated, confirm if stove and oven have separate power connections
Kitchen fire suppression system is shown, fuel shut-off solenoid / contactor power as required
Photocopier, printers, computer outlets indicated

Auto door openers are provided at principal building entrance, parkade vestibules to elevator lobbies, and anywhere noted on the architectural drawings (power, push plates, xfer hinges, electromagnetic locks coordinated)
Power door operator buttons for ADOs required by 3.8.2.7.(1) are indicated at both mounting heights: (150mm-300mm and 900mm-1100mm)
Door hardware coordinated with architect
Hand dryers/automatic faucets/flush valves - connect electronic valves to non life safety standby power where available
Check outlets with millwork details, obstructions, furniture locations and modular furniture connections
Receptacle mounting details specified and are constructable
Vandal resistant devices where appropriate (locker room, washroom, exterior, corridors)
GFCI receptacles: exterior (within 2.5m of grade), interior (within 1.5m of sink, tub, shower)
AFCI breakers/outlets for dwelling units
Split or T-slot receptacles at kitchen counter, island, peninsula

Island counter receptacles (20A T-slot) are provided for each work surface larger than 300mm x 600mm. If a sink or stove is placed in the centre of an island, it creates a work suface on either side if it so that a receptacle is required on each end. Ensure this is coordinated with interior designer so that the backboxes do not conflict with drawers, appliances, or waterfall counter edges.
Rough in for automatic door provided at suite entrance where latchside clearance is less than 450mm
Garbage compactor has power connection (if load unknown, assume 10HP)
Parkade maintenance receptacles are detailed so that all portions of the parking area are within 25' of a receptacle. Mounted indicated at 48" AFF
All parking gates have power with a note to provide 4-wire connection
EVSE outlets indicated per municipal by-law requirements. Branch circuit groupings indicated if applicable and comply with by-law EVEMS allowances.
Correctional grade, including anchorage, placement, and security caulking
Tamper resistant receptacles indicated for child care facilities, guest rooms and suites of hotels/motels, preschool and elementary schools, and dwelling units
Tamper resistant receptacles indicated for areas accessible to children
Outdoor receptacles indicated as weatherproof
CSA outlet configurations indicated for special receptacles (5-20R, etc)
Patient care bonding (exposed conductive parts connected at panel or room reference)
Hospital grade receptacles (voltage drop, dedicated neutral, same size bond, insulated bond, extra circuits)
Colour coded receptacles (Vital/UPS/Emergency), installation in accordance with Z32
Power/comm coordination with pre-wired medical service units
Power/comm coordination with medical equipment suppliers (imaging, fume hoods, bio-safety cabinets, MIS)
Coordination with infection control requirements (sealing rooms)
All devices and equipment have been circuited, with correct breaker and wire sizes in single line and/or schedules
GFCI protection provided for all branch circuits below ground level in areas designated as flood hazard zones
Loads and starter / disconnect switch / voltage, emergency power branch, FLA, MCA, MOCP confirmed with mechanical consultant
Heat loads for electrical and communication service rooms provided to mechanical consultant to size HVAC
Mechanical equipment locations are coordinated with correct tags and power connections shown
Motorized damper and fire/smoke damper locations are coordinated with power connections (and smoke detectors for smoke dampers) shown.
Heat tracing of sprinkler and plumbing pipes in exterior spaces, unheated areas, and parkades shown.
30mA (Class B) ground fault protection provided for heat tracing
All notes of schedules on mech drawings have been checked for additional electrical connections missed by mech consultant on motorlist (electronic trap primers, 120V controls, etc.)
Short circuit / withstand current ratings are included in mech equipment spec, matching available fault current
Confirm with mechanical if a separate air dryer circuit is needed for air compressors
Marine lights / outlet connections required for AHU
Roof mounted receptacles near mechanical equipment (WP, GFCI, 5-20R)
Electric heaters and line voltage thermostats to be specified by electrical or mechanical? (coordinate with mech consultant)
Thermostats for electrical heaters indicated on plans (external/integrated); relay provided where >3kW is on a single thermostat; thermostsats located away from windows and heaters.
Class A GFCI protection specified for heating devices located within 1m of sinks, tubs, or shower stalls.
Class A GFCI protection specified for thermostats less than 1m from a sink, tub, or shower stall. No thermostats within 500mm of a tub or shower stall.
Heating devices are provided branch circuits that only serve heating devices
Current sensor is shown on clothes dryer circuit to turn on dryer booster fan (confirm with mechanical)
ERV/HRV control coordinated with mech (possibly 2-speed with 120V control interlocked with lighting)
Emergency circuit for block heater and battery charger
Fuel pump, damper controls, and lighting in generator room on emergency power
Fixed temperature heat detectors in generator room, if room is not sprinklered
Common trouble to fire alarm (if connected) annunciator
Bypass Isolation is required in a transfer switch (dual bypass for group B2 healthcare, single emerg side bypass for B1/B3 institutional or group C residential)
If transfer switch is intended for interconnection with utility, and the utility requirements for parallel power sources are met
Confirmed all required life safety and non-life-safety emergency loads, conforming with the code consultant's report
Outdoor Generators: Min. 1.2m from property line, 3m from building wall that contains any opening within 3-storeys above and 5m horizontally from generator
Elevator machine room / control room / controller in elevator door jamb is illuminated to 200lx at the floor level.
Elevator machine room / control room / controller in elevator door jamb is provided a receptacle (GFCI required per 38-085(2))
Elevator pit provided lighting to 100lx. Light is guarded to prevent breakage, switch provided at pit access door.
Receptacle provided in elevator pit (GFCI required per 38-085(1))
Top of elevator shaft light, switch, and GFCI receptacle provided (required for machine room-less designs as the top of shaft is considered 'machine space' by CSA B44)
Each elevator door threshold is illuminated to 100lx at the floor level.

Lighting of elevator door thresholds is on separate control zone from other area lighting and is 24/7 operation. (TSBC interprets B44 2.11.10.2 as meaning all thresholds should be illuminated to 100lx when the elevator is operating, regardless of the presence of occupants at each floor level)
Telephone and card access provisions at each elevator controller.
Each elevator controller / car provided a fused disconnect in the elevator machine room / control room
Each elevator car provided a fused disconnect in the elevator machine room for cab lighting, HVAC
MRL elevators: Where no machine room or control room is provided, space in a service room is provided for the disconnecting means required by CEC 38-051.
MRL elevators: Where no machine room or control room is provided, space in a service room is provided for the elevator manufacturer provided transformer.
Elevator controller disconnect is c/w auxiliary contact where battery lowering provided.
Regenerative braking considerations - sufficient means of absorbing regenerative power while on emergency power is provided.
Machine room details on drawings
Elevator emergency return is provided upon actuation of shaft, lobby, or elevator machine room detectors
Smoke detector(s) is provided in elevator machine room
A smoke detector is provided at the top of each elevator shaft
A heat detector is provided in the elevator pit where the pit is considered 'machine space' containing an elevator controller or driving machine (typical for MRL or hydraulic elevators)
A smoke detector is provided in the elevator lobby of each floor served by the elevator, coordinated with bulkheads/drop ceiling elements

An illuminated signal â€œElevator Emergency Powerâ€ is provided in the elevator lobby of the recall levels to indicate that the emergency power is in effect (Coordinate with elevator consultant - elec may only provide signal from ATS to elevator controller)
Code Blue over-ride of elevator recall (variance - not FAS requirement)
Elevator machine room / control room lighting on emergency if available, provided dedicated circuit.
Elevator machine room / control room receptacles on standby if available, provided dedicated circuit.
Elevator pit lighting/switchand receptacles on standby if available, provided dedicated circuit.
Heat trace of sprinkler system is provided supervisory monitoring by FAS
Supervisory monitoring (float switch) for any onsite sprinkler water storage
Sprinkler valve tamper switches, flow switches and supervisory devices shown on plans (including water entry room and standpipes)
Power connections for compressors of dry systems (serving unheated areas) have been coordinated with sprinkler drawings
Signal to fire department is required, fire alarm transmitter detailed as close as practicable to FACP (ULC S561 Article 9.5.1.2)
Annunciator locations detailed and wall depth coordinated with arch (typically 24"W x 8"D). Outdoor annunciators are approved for use in exterior applications (CEC 2-024(1)).
Fire Alarm Zone Schedule provided, includes all alarm, supervisory, and speaker zones.
Fire alarm zones clearly identified as keyplan and/or riser.
Zoning / fire separations for patient relocation compartments in patient sleeping areas [3.3.3.5 of NBC], areas of refuge [3.3.3.6 of NBC], and contained use areas [3.3.3.7 of NBC]
Weatherproof devices indicated for exterior applications and where operating temperature may be below 0Â°C
Protective covers specified where required for security or where susceptible to damage (gyms, potential for vandalism, etc.). Covers meet requiremetns of S524 Section 25.
Fire alarm design for row housing not more than 4 storeys
Radio Antenna System (E-Comm) provided
Radio Antenna System (E-Comm) provided (check municipal by-laws for requirements)
1P/15A dedicated circuit for fire alarm control panel (on life safety emergency and/or battery backup), lockable red breaker
1P/15A dedicated circuit for fire alarm transmitter  (on life safety emergency, if available)
Smoke alarms are required (in dwelling units / sleeping rooms)
Smoke alarms are required (in dwelling units / sleeping rooms)
At least one smoke alarm is installed on each storey of a dwelling unit or suite of care occupancy.
Smoke alarm provided in each sleeping room, and between each sleeping room and the remainder of living space.
Hotels and motels: 10% of rooms have a combo 120V smoke/strobe alarm.
No smoke alarms are located within 3m of stove, within 1m of bathroom door header, or within 1m of AC vent [ULC S553]
Smoke alarms shall be connected to a lighting circuit

CO Alarms provided in suites of residential or care occupancies containing fuel-burning appliances, or share a wall or floor/ceiling assembly with a service room containing fuel-burning appliances or a parking garage

CO Alarms provided in suites of residential occupancies containing fuel-burning appliances, or share a wall or floor/ceiling assembly with a service room containing fuel-burning appliances or a parking garage
CO Alarms in assembly, business and personal services, and mercantile occupancies.
Audible (horns or speakers) indicated throughout floor areas, audibility confirmed.
Audible devices not placed in exit stairs, except for speakers forming part of a voice communication system per NBC 3.2.4.22.(1)(b) and 3.2.4.23.(2)(b)
Audible devices provided for occupied exterior spaces (mechanical service areas, outdoor amenities, etc.) - Not specifically in NBC but is a common AHJ interpretation / requirement
An audible device is provided in each sleeping room of a residential or care occupancy to ensure 75dBA requirement is met.
Audible signal silence buttons are provided in all dwelling units. Button mounted between 1050mm - 1150mm AFF (S524-29 Artcile 41.1)

For 2 Stage FAS systems, 1st stage alert signals and ancillary system actions are clearly defined (e.g. T3 signal in initiating zone, 20bpm chime in adjacent zones, door releases in initiating & adjacent zones)
Audible devices provided for residential balconies
Strobe lights are provided in rooms above 87dBA ambient
Strobe lights are provided in public corridors of Group B, C, D, or E major occupancies, and corridors serving Group A major occupancies. (not required in earlier code editions)
Strobe lights are provided in 10% of suites of residential occupancy in a hotel or motel
Strobe lights are provided in washrooms, except those within suites of residential or care occupancies, or patient sleeping rooms
Strobe light layouts are in compliance with ULC S524 requirements (refer to S524-19 Table 42.1, Figure 42.2, and Figure D.1, D.2, and D.3)

Exterior fire strobe at entrance where required by municipality or Code Report (main entrance for City of Edmonton, blue strobe at firefighters' entry for Langford/Colwood always and in other municipalities when multiple buildings are on one property)
Adaptable dwelling units are provided outlet boxes and cover plates for future strobes in each sleeping room, room closed off from the living area by a door, and living area
Adaptable dwelling units are provided outlet boxes and cover plates for future strobes in each sleeping room, room closed off from the living area by a door, and living area
Dwelling units in buildings designed for seniors have special outlet boxes and cover plates for future strobes
Dwelling units in buildings designed for seniors have special outlet boxes and cover plates for future strobes
Multilevel residential suites provided strobe at suite entrance
Smoke detectors in patient sleeping rooms and between there and exit
Smoke detectors in cells and between there and exit
Smoke detectors in corridors of A1 occupancies (theatres)
Smoke detectors in residential building public corridors
Smoke detectors at top of all exit stairwells
Smoke detectors provided on every third floor of exit stairwells that measure >18m from the lowest point to the highest point of the stair shaft (floor to ceiling)
Smoke detectors and exhaust fan control for interconnected floor spaces (see 3.2.8.7 for fan control requirements) (see S524-19 Article 28.4 for detector locations)
Smoke detectors provided in vestibules between interconnected buildings, and near walkways connecting buildings
Smoke detector in unsprinklered electrical rooms or vaults
Conventional devices with remote addressible modules provided in locations unsuitable for addressable devices.
Fire detector in liquid-filled transformer vaults shuts down ventilation
Fire detectors provided in rooms listed in 3.2.4.10.(2) for buildings requiring a fire alarm system, but no sprinkler system
Detectors shown under stages, in crawl spaces and under stairs
Duct detectors in AHUs (supply side, where units serve more than one floor/occupancy or units share return air plenum - confirm with mechanical Engineer) See S524-19 Article 31.2
Duct detectors in AHUs that serve multiple dwelling units See S524-19 Article 31.2
Smoke / fire detectors laid out based on 6.4m protection radius
Smoke / fire detector spacing has been reduced for ceiling heights over 3m.
Manual stations at every building or floor exit door
Manual stations in staff areas (healthcare)
CO Alarms provided in service rooms containing fuel-burning appliances
CO Alarms provided in service rooms containing fuel-burning appliances
Audible / visual indicator of patient room/cell smoke for attendant (annunciator at nursing/guard station) [3.2.4.11.1(c) of NBC]
Smoke detectors for cells are aspiration/air sampling type (duct smoke or VESDA)
Audible / visual indicator of cell smoke
CACF location detailed (typically 3 tubs 28"W x 8"D).
FACP location detailed in 1-hour rated electrical room (typically 2 tubs 28"W x 8"D)
Voice communication is required
Audible devices are detailed as speakers throughout
Firefighter's handsets (phones) are provided within 1.5m of all exit stair doors
Manual switches for operation of smoke control & smoke venting equip. at CACF indicated on Mechanical Schedule (info provided by mech consultant)
Door hold open devices indicated if required (c/w releasing smokes per ULC-S524)
Electromagnetic locks (requirements coordinated, reset switch location identified)
Commercial kitchen - fire suppression system connected to FAS, on separate zone per 3.2.4.8.(2)(e)
Separate audible signal circuits are provided for each floor area
Audible signal devices in dwelling units or suites of residential or care occupancies are on separate signal circuits from audible devices in the rest of the floor area
Audible signal device circuits serving dwelling units or suites of residential or care occupancies are Class 'A', or Class 'A' with suite fault isolators.
Amplifiers / transponders shown every 5 floors in high buildings, located in 1-hour rated electrical room / closet.
All stairways and elevator shafts indicated.
Protection of fire alarm conductors indicated.
Fault isolator / wiring configuration in compliance with Data Communication Link requirements of Section 19 of S524
Any connections indicated for 120V, BMS, monitoring, etc. are connected to the FACP, not the annunciator or CACF.
Control units / transponders have dedicated 1P/15A circuits indicated (from life safety emergency power, if available).
Goals/constraints have been confirmed with client (if applicable). Power production goals, payback period goals, budget, aesthetics.
System has been modelled and has good performance. Client goals have been met.
System is under 100kW on the AC side (inverter output rating) for BC Hydro Net Metering.
If system is over 100kW, client is aware of additional BC Hydro studies and costs involved.
BC Hydro Net Metering or Distribution Generator Interconnection application paperwork shall be provided by contractor (add note).
Photovoltaic Rapid Shutdown is provided.
DC Arc-Fault Protection has been provided.
Utility Disconnecting Means and Equipment Disconnecting Means have been provided.

String voltage is higher than inverter minimum MPPT voltage. String voltage is lower than maximum allowable inverter input voltage. Total current of all combined strings is lower than maximum allowable inverter input current.
For installations on Dwelling Units, system voltage does not exceed 600VDC.
Overcurrent devices and disconnecting means are suitable to be backfed (bi directional).
Combiner boxes have been provided as required.

Panel board busbar for photovoltaic inverter point of interconnection has been sized such that it is rated for minimum 120% of the ampere rating of overcurrent devices in source circuits supplying power to the panel board.
Warning Labels have been allowed for at all required locations.
Ethernet, USB, or Power Line Communications connections have been provided for data logging and monitoring of the inverters.

Conductor and conduit sizing is complete. Voltage drop has been accounted for.
